paragraph.heading:
Cymbella yerlii C.N.Solak, S.Blanco & N.Balkis-Ozdelice
,
sp. nov.
( Figs 16–35 )

subSubSection.paragraph: Description: Valves slightly to moderately dorsiventral, lanceolate, dorsal margin distinctly convex, ventral margin slightly tumid. Ends indistinctly protracted and rounded ( Table 2 ). Length 31.8–45.8 μm, breadth 7.4–9.0 μm, maximal length/breadth ratio of the normal cells 5.3. Axial area narrow, linear, central area absent. Raphe slightly ventrally displaced, lateral, becoming filiform near the distal and filiform to weakly reverse-lateral near the proximal ends [ type “ e ” according to Krammer (2002 : Fig. 67: 3)]. Striae parallel at the central area, becoming slightly radiate near the ends, finely punctate. A distinct isolated 1–2 stigmata are visible just at the end of the central stria on the ventral side. In the SEM, 1–2 slit-like stigma foramina. Parallel arranged pore field alveoli only on the valve end. The margins of the stigma alveoli are provided with teeth-like structures. Striae in the middle portion (dorsal and ventral) 9–10/10 μm, rising to 13–15/10 μm towards the ends, puncta 24–28/10 μm.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 16–25. Light micrographs of
Cymbella yerlii sp. nov.
Scale bar = 10 µm.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
TURKEY , Sakarbaşı , Eskişehir ( GPS 39°21’10.04’’N , 31°03’33.24’’E ),
872 m a.s.l.
, collector: Cüneyt Nadir Solak
24.11.2019
. Holotype : slide number 27354 ( holotype designated here on Fig. 1 ) in the collection of Andrzej Witkowski at the University of Szczecin.

and

sharing similar morphological features.

7–9, becoming up to 12 towards to end
6.5–9, becoming up to 11 towards to end
7–9, becoming up to 12 towards to end
9–12, becoming up to 12 towards to end
6–8(9) dorsal, 8–9 ventral, becoming up to 12 towards to end
8–12, becoming up to 14 towards to end
3-6 large elliptical stigma foramina and 1-4 smaller round stigma foramina
striae dorsally more distant, broad lateral raphe

Cymbella yerlii sp. nov.
and
Cymbella species
sharing similar morphological features.

tr.td: 9–11 (dorsal and ventral), 13–15 towards to ends parallel striation at central area, slightly radiate at the end
8–9 dorsal, about 10 ventral, 14–15 towards to ends
slightly to moderately dorsiventral, lanceolate, dorsal margin convex, ventral margin nearly straight or somewhat slightly tumid at the centre
moderately dorsiventral,, elliptic lanceolate, dorsal margin distinctly convex, ventral margin slightly convex to straight
slightly to moderately dorsiventral, lanceolate, dorsal margin convex, ventral margin slightly convex
moderately to strongly dorsiventral, semilanceolate, dorsal margin distinctly convex, ventral margin nearly straight or somewhat tumid in the centre
strongly dorsiventral, semilanceolate, dorsal margin districtly convex, ventral margin nearly straight
variable from barely protracted to slightly or moderately protracted
not or indistinctly protracted and rounded

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 26–31. SEM micrographs of
Cymbella yerlii sp. nov.
26. External view of entire valve, 27. External view of central area showing striae composed of slit-like areolae, rounded-rectangular stigmata and the proximal raphe endings, 28, 29. External view of valve apex showing apical pore field, 30. Girdle view of entire valve, 31. Girdle view of valve apex showing apical pore field. Scale bars 10 µm (Figs 26, 30), 5 µm (Figs 27–29, 31).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Isotype:—
Slide no. TR_ ESK _Sakarbası_
Nov2019
_EPF deposited at Kütahya Dumlupınar University ( Turkey )
.
Etymology:— The species was dedicated to Prof. Dr. Sedat YERLİ who is a hydrobiologist in Turkey .

Differential diagnosis:—
Cymbella parva (W. Smith) Kirchner
in Cohn (1878: 188),
C. perparva Krammer (2002: 37)
and
C. parviformis Krammer (2002: 38)
and
Cymbella tridentina H.Lange-Bertalot, M.Cantonati & A.Scalfi
in
Cantonati et al. (2010: 778)
are similar taxa. Among them,
C. parva
is the most similar taxon in all related ones with similar outline. However, length/width ratio is higher in
C. yerlii
than the other taxa. In
C. parviformis
, striae density in dorsal and ventral sides are lower than
C. yerlii
. Regarding to the apices, the shape is non protracted and narrowly rounded in
C. parva
and
C. parviformis
while, indistindtly protracted and rounded in
C. yerlii
and
C. parviformis
.
Distribution:— Observed only in the type locality.
Ecology:— The water temperature ranged from 21.4–22.9 oC , pH was 7.8–7.9, dissolved oxygen (DO) was 5.2– 6.1 mg /L and electrolytic conductivity was 545–575 µS/ cm-1 .

Associated diatom flora:—
Cymbella cymbiformis
(21.2%),
Encyonopsis minuta Krammer & E.Reichardt
in Krammer (1997: 95) (10.5%),
Amphora pediculus (Kützing) Grunow
[described as
Cymbella pediculus Kützing (1844: 80)
] (5.3%),
Navicula cryptotenella Lange-Bertalot
in Krammer & Lange-Bertalot (1985: 62) (4.1%),
Eunotia arcubus Nörpel & Lange-Bertalot
in Lange-Bertalot (1993: 24) (3.8%),
Nitzschia gracilis Hantzsch (1860: 40)
(2.9%), Staurosira construens Ehrenberg (1843: 424) (2.5%),
Pseudostaurosira brevistriata (Grunow) D.M. Williams & Round (1988: 276)
(2.2%),
Staurosirella pinnata (Ehrenberg) D.M. Williams & Round (1988: 274)
(1.9%), unidentified species of
Brachysira Kützing
,
Cocconeis Ehrenberg
,
Pseudostaurosira D.M.Williams & Round
and
Sellaphora Kützing
were the most frequent taxa in the sample.
